div.head: none
div.summary: William H. Seward declares the Democratic caucus's proscription of Stephen Douglas's presidential candidacy a sure sign of an "irrepressable conflict between Freedom and Slavery" in the United States. The action illustrates "a settled determination to tolerate no diversity of opinion upon any measure which the South demanded."

page.pageNote: Page covered by fiction and human interest stories.

div.head: The Speakership
div.excerpt: "Col. A.K. McClure, our worthy and talented Representative at Harrisbburg, failed to secure the Caucus nomination, for Speaker, by four votes."
div.summary: Representative Alexander K. McClure of Franklin County failed to win the speakership of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives by the margin of four votes.

page.pageNote: Most of this page is occupied by a lengthy Republican tariff harangue of the usual sort. The Repository blasts the Philadelphia Argus as "an acknowledged blow-pipe of the imbecile national administration."

div.head: John G. Saxe
div.summary: Verse by verse commentary on the work of the poet Mr. Saxe.

div.head: "Lecture on Politics by Geo. D. Prentice"
div.summary: Mr. Prentice, editor of the Louisville Journal and former editor of the New England Weekly Review, delivered a jeremiad on the state of American politics from an ostensibly "no party" perspective. He pronounced all politicians "knaves" and reserved special criticism for the Buchanan administration. The Repository noted that it "could...perceive the old line Clay Whig `bringing up' of the speaker..."

div.head: "Agricultural Society"
div.excerpt: "The friends of Agriculture, the improvement of Animal Stock, Farming Implements, Fruit, Vegetables and Household Manufactures, are requested to meet at the COURT HOUSE in Chambersburg on Tuesday evening, the 13 of January, inst. at 6 1/2 o`clock to organize an AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY in and for the county of Franklin."

div.head: "Appalling Calamity: Three Children Burned to Death!"
div.summary: Mr. Bender's three children died in a fire at his home while he was at work at Mr. Campbell's tannery in Hersheytown "about a mile distant," and his wife in the barn milking cows. The story provides gruesome detail as to the "young sufferers" physical appearances upon their removal from the gutted house.

div.head: "Trial List for January Term, 1859: First Week"
"Trial List for January Term, 1859: Second Week:
Traverse Jurors, for January Term, 1859: Second Week>
div.note: Some names and occupations are blurry or otherwise obscured. Some indviduals have no occupation noted.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Married 22nd of December; no church noted. Both of Letterkenny Township.

div.head: married
div.summary: Married on December 28. No church noted.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Married on December 28 at the Indian Queen Hotel.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Died December 13, near Alto Dale; aged 66 years, 9 months and 8 days.

div.head: Died
div.summary: John A. Wingert, aged 5 years, 1 month and 5 days, died on December 14.

page.pageNote: Remainder of page covered by advertisements and poetry.
